intro: Ammi diversifolium var. daucifolium, commonly known as the narrow-leaved cow-wheat, is a biennial or short-lived perennial herb native to the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and umbellate inflorescences. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in sagebrush steppe and grassland habitats. Its leaves are narrow and pinnately divided, while its flowers are small and white, arranged in clusters. It plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for certain herbivores.
